issue.title: Using the '--prior-strength' option causes training to crash

content.raw: Hi Eric – We’re working on a new round of ENCODE Segway annotations and we’d like to use --prior-strength. Is there any plan to fix this issue? Thanks!
content.html: Hi Eric – We’re working on a new round of ENCODE Segway annotations and we’d like to use --prior-strength. Is there any plan to fix this issue? Thanks!

issue.title: Using the '--prior-strength' option causes training to crash

content.raw: `--prior-strength` never really had much of the desired effect. The segTransition-weight-scale option has a bigger effect.
content.html: --prior-strength never really had much of the desired effect. The segTransition-weight-scale option has a bigger effect.

issue.title: Using the '--prior-strength' option causes training to crash

content.raw: I did some experiments about this a while ago. I believe the result was that using --segtransition-weight-scale was only effective with --prior-strength as well. I think the value of --prior-strength itself wasn’t too important, but it was important that it was nonzero. The experiments have been archived now, so they’re hard to dig up, unfortunately.
content.html: I did some experiments about this a while ago. I believe the result was that using --segtransition-weight-scale was only effective with --prior-strength as well. I think the value of --prior-strength itself wasn’t too important, but it was important that it was nonzero. The experiments have been archived now, so they’re hard to dig up, unfortunately.

issue.title: Using the '--prior-strength' option causes training to crash

content.raw: If I recall correctly this error was from a regression involving the mixture of gaussians change \(where `--prior-strength` is not actively tested\). We switched over from a Dirichlet Table to constants instead. Last I took a cursory look at this, there is a non-trivial amount of work to resurrect the table and re-introduce it for the `--prior-strenth` option. Obviously it would be ideal if you could get equivalent or better results without using it. As far as plans go this issue is unfortunately not currently high on my todo list but may move up depending on how @hoffman wishes to triage this issue in particular.
content.html: If I recall correctly this error was from a regression involving the mixture of gaussians change (where --prior-strength is not actively tested). We switched over from a Dirichlet Table to constants instead. Last I took a cursory look at this, there is a non-trivial amount of work to resurrect the table and re-introduce it for the --prior-strenth option. Obviously it would be ideal if you could get equivalent or better results without using it. As far as plans go this issue is unfortunately not currently high on my todo list but may move up depending on how @hoffman wishes to triage this issue in particular.
